title: How to Make a Scottish Whisky Dundee Cake

steps.headline: Weigh the fruit and peel and place into a bowl, sprinkling it with the 3 tablespoons (44.4 ml) whiskey.
Mix well, cover and leave overnight.
Preheat the oven to gas mark 3, 325°F or 170°C.
Put the butter and sugar in a mixing bowl and beat with a wooden spoon until light and fluffy.
Whisk the eggs separately then, a little at a time, beat them into the creamed butter and sugar.
Fold in the sifted flour and baking powder carefully, using a large tablespoon.
Add a dessertspoon of milk if the mixture seems too dry.
steps.description: The mixture needs to be of a soft, dropping consistency.

steps.headline: Fold in the ground almonds, currants, sultanas, cherries, mixed peel and orange and lemon rinds carefully.
Grease the cake tin and line it with greaseproof paper.
Spoon the mixture into the prepared cake tin, smoothing it out evenly with the back of the spoon.
Arrange the whole blanched almonds in circles on the top of the mixture, if you don't intend to ice the cake.
Place the cake in the centre of the oven and bake for 2-21/2 hours or until the centre is firm and springy to touch.
Let the cake cool in the tin for 30 minutes before taking it out to finish cooling on a wire rack.
Feed it, wrap it in double greaseproof paper and store it in foil or an airtight container 'till needed.
Finished.
steps.description: A Dundee cake improves in taste by being left a few days to mature before being cut and served.

text: Weigh the fruit and peel and place into a bowl, sprinkling it with the 3 tablespoons (44.4 ml) whiskey.  Mix well, cover and leave overnight.  Preheat the oven to gas mark 3, 325°F or 170°C.  Put the butter and sugar in a mixing bowl and beat with a wooden spoon until light and fluffy.  Whisk the eggs separately then, a little at a time, beat them into the creamed butter and sugar.  Fold in the sifted flour and baking powder carefully, using a large tablespoon.  Add a dessertspoon of milk if the mixture seems too dry. The mixture needs to be of a soft, dropping consistency. Fold in the ground almonds, currants, sultanas, cherries, mixed peel and orange and lemon rinds carefully.  Grease the cake tin and line it with greaseproof paper.  Spoon the mixture into the prepared cake tin, smoothing it out evenly with the back of the spoon.  Arrange the whole blanched almonds in circles on the top of the mixture, if you don't intend to ice the cake.  Place the cake in the centre of the oven and bake for 2-21/2 hours or until the centre is firm and springy to touch.  Let the cake cool in the tin for 30 minutes before taking it out to finish cooling on a wire rack.  Feed it, wrap it in double greaseproof paper and store it in foil or an airtight container 'till needed.  Finished. A Dundee cake improves in taste by being left a few days to mature before being cut and served.
